UNODC:Improving SRHR outcomes of women & youth in prison settings in Sub-SA 2016

description.narrative:
The improvement of the prison setting conditions within the minimum requirements set out in the UN Standard and Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners, and other international and regional standards and norms will be measured by expected outcomes; Objective 1: Strengthening the capacity of national governments to put in place legal, policy and strategy instruments that adhere to UN Minimum standards of HIV/AIDS and SRHR for prison populations. Objective 2: National capacity built to enable adoption and implementation of measures necessary for national adherence to HIV/ AIDS and SRHR minimum standards for women and adolescent prisoners. Objective 3: Supporting the development of HIV/AIDS and SRHR services to meet the needs of women and adolescent populations in Sub-Saharan African prison systems.
The following information is about the hand-over The contact person with UNODC is Ms. Signe Rotberga signe.rotberga@un.org Owing to the present global health status, Ms. Rotberga is telecommuting for Southern Africa region from Latvia. She and her team in the region remain committed to ensure a successful completion regarding Swedish support. The implementation period of the intervention expired on April 30 2020. The agreed up-coming reports includes: i) Revision of annual progress report for period 1 January 2019 to 30 April 2020. ii) Annual Financial Statement for period 1 January 2019 to 30 April 2020. iii) Final programme report covering the whole period. iv) Final programme financial statement covering the whole period There is no outstanding disbursement to the intervention - The cooperation with UNODC has generally flowed smoothly. The partner showed capacity to adhere to agreement conditions. Except for financial statements, narrative progress reports have been timely presented. Because certified statements are generating by a UN “UMOJA” system, UNODC is unfortunately drawn into the system’s shortcoming of delayed submission of statements. - UNODC informed Sida of realised financial irregularities halfway through final implementation period of the intervention. Presently, Sida awaits a UNODC internal audit report on the matter. - The partner revealed failure to successfully commission an external end of programme evaluation within granted no cost extension period Jan 2020 to April 2020. Sida has requested for details in the expected revised annual progress report for period 1 January 2019 to 30 April 2020. - Important to note is that, there has been an unfortunate turnover of a few key staff at both, regional and national levels. Hopefully, it will not affect UNODC’s ability to present “good enough” quality of awaited reports.

UNODC's 3-year programme aims at improving SRHR outcomes of women and young people in prison settings in Sub-Saharan Africa in nine countries in Sub-Saharan Africa: Angola, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia, and Zimbabwe). The problem will be addressed through supporting the adoption and operationalisation of the UN Minimum Standards and Rule in relation to all prisoners retain the basic inalienable human rights that apply to all human beings, including the right to the highest attainable standard of physical and mental health. These standards and rule include; the Nelson Mandela Rules, the Bangkok Rules, the Beijing Rules as well as in international instruments such as the International Convention on the Rights of the Child, that inter alia require adolescent prisoners and detainees to be separated from adult prisoners.

UNODC's program som skall implemtenteras under 2017-19 syftar till att förbättra den sexuella och reproduktiva hälsan och rättigheterna för kvinnor och ungdomar i fängelser i Afrika söder om Sahara i nio länder söder om Sahara i Afrika: Angola, Lesotho, Malawi, Moçambique, Namibia, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia och Zimbabwe). UNODC skall göra detta genom att stödja länderna att anta och implementera FN:s miniminormer och regelverk för att säkra mänskliga rättigheter i fängelsemiljöer. Denna fas fokuserar på kvinnor och unga personer i fängelse.

description.narrative: During the period January 2018 - Deceber 2018, UNODC worked at the global, regional and national levels promoting changes on the policy and legal frameworks in line with UN normative standards on HIV/AIDS and SRHR for the prison populations. The following examples of results were achieved: Objective 1: Strengthening the capacity of national governments to put in place legal, policy and strategy instruments that adhere to UN Minimum standards of HIV/AIDS and SRHR for prison populations. - Partnered with Southern African Development Community Parliamentary Forum (SADC PF), African Correctional Services Association (ACSA) and African HIV and Health in Prison Partnership Network (AHPPN) and organized an extraordinary policy sensitisation session for ACSA Members. Discussions bordered on sensitive topics such as human rights, SRH, access to condoms and other prevention commodities in prisons. - A Communiqué “A call for action to foster the practical application of the Nelson Mandela Rules, including compliance with HIV, health and human rights principles for people in prisons in Africa” was adopted by ACSA. - Contributed to development of Minimum Standards for KPs in the context of HIV and AIDS in the SADC region. The Standards promote policy and legal changes from a parliamentary perspective and reinforce the SADC Regional Strategy for HIV and AIDS Prevention, Treatment and Care and SRHR among Key Populations endorsed in November 2017 by SADC Ministers responsible for health and HIV and AIDS. - Supported revisions and drafting of policy amendments in Malawi, Zanzibar and Lesotho to comply with the UN normative guidelines for HIV/AIDS and SRHR as enshrined in the Nelson Mandela. - Amplified advocacy on improving prison systems relating to pregnancies among females in prisons in Zambia, partnerships with the Zambia Law Development Commission and Criminal Justice Sector Leadership. - Coordinated 4 assessments in; Malawi, Zambia, Namibia, Mozambique, which will inform governments towards efforts on compliance with Nelson Mandela Rules and guide development of cost and action combined plans. - Conducted a rapid assessment of policy, system and service delivery gaps in Namibia’s 13 Correctional Facilities using the Rapid Assessment Tool (RAT) for SRH and HIV Linkages developed by IPPF, UNFAP, WHO, UNAIDS, GNP, ICWW, Young. - Enabled participation of six delegates representatives from African correctional services of implementing countries at the 22nd International AIDS Conference (AIDS 2018) in Amsterdam. - Convened a satellite session on “Supporting Regional Compliance with HIV, health and rights minimum standards for prison populations of Sub-Saharan Africa”, at 22nd IAC. - Supported ACSA develop, draft and submit to member nations an "institution Constitution" required to legally transform ACSA to African intergovernmental body on prisons. An unexpected result is that the programme supported the government of Nigeria conduct a situation and needs assessment of HIV/AIDS and related health services in Nigerian prisons. Objective 2: National capacity built to enable adoption and implementation of measures necessary for national adherence to HIV/AIDS and SRHR minimum standards for women and adolescent prisoners. - Reached and equipped about 720 prison officers and management, plus health and CSO actors through capacity and knowledge building trainings on HIV and AIDS, TB, SRH and general prison health management as provisioned in the UN normative guidelines. - Supported development of an academic curriculum for African Prisons and Corrections Staff in line with the provisions of the Nelson Mandela Rules. To be hosted within Namibia Correctional Service training college and accredited by Namibia University of Science. - Facilitated peer-to-peer learning between Mozambique’s and Lesotho’s Correctional Services (MCS and LCS) on legal and policy position regarding LCS’ practice of providing condoms and lubricants in prison settings. - Facilitated representation of Lesotho, Malawi, Namibia, Zambia and Zimbabwe in an expert group meeting in Vienna for the development of a Technical Guide for Prevention of Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT) of HIV in prisons. This guide will support countries in providing high quality HIV and SRH services to women in prisons and ensure elimination of new HIV infections among women and their children in prisons. Objective 3: Supporting the development of HIV/AIDS and SRHR services to meet the needs of women and adolescent populations in Sub-Saharan African prison systems. - Supported educational and information sessions at Correctional Services in all implementing countries to visibly commemorate World Cancer Day, World AIDS Day, and World Tuberculosis Day.
